ranked_diseases.disease_name: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency
ranked_diseases.explanation: Clitoral hypertrophy and hyperpigmentation are common features of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which is the most common cause of CAH. The hyperpigmentation can result from elevated ACTH levels due to impaired cortisol synthesis.

ranked_diseases.disease_name: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency
ranked_diseases.explanation: This form of CAH can also present with clitoral hypertrophy and hyperpigmentation due to similar mechanisms as 21-hydroxylase deficiency, though it is less common.
This condition can present with hyperpigmentation due to elevated ACTH levels, though clitoral hypertrophy is less commonly associated.
Addison disease can cause hyperpigmentation due to elevated ACTH levels, but clitoral hypertrophy is not a typical feature, making it less likely.
This syndrome can present with hyperpigmentation (café-au-lait spots) and rarely with clitoral hypertrophy due to endocrine dysfunction, though it is a less common association.
